image.altText: A woman and a child with a crowd around them

items.synopsis: For 10 years, the Alkamilya Football Club has provided a sisterhood for Indigenous women in Alice Springs, with the recent loss of its founding member, Magic, ultimately bringing the players closer.

title.children: There are many challenges for Indigenous women in Alice Springs, but on the field they are victors

image.altText: A surfer drinks water on a hot day in Sydney, 2013

items.synopsis: The prospect of an El Niño climate pattern has made headlines for months now, but while ocean temperatures are strongly favouring its development, the atmosphere still hasn't kicked into gear. So what's going on?

title.children: Climate scientists say they've 'never seen anything' like this year's potential El Niño event as it inches closer

image.altText: Aboriginal flag in being waved front of a crowd of people in Melbourne streets.

items.synopsis: People intending to vote Yes at next month's Voice referendum are marching across Australia today.

title.children: Supporters of Indigenous Voice to Parliament gather for events across Australia

image.altText: A composite image of a smiling woman next to a polaroid of herself in kindergarten.

items.synopsis: How is it that I, a middle-aged woman with career success living a life far more secure than that of many, can be feeling so reduced to nothingness by some of the discourse in the Voice debate, asks Miriam Corowa.

title.children: I'm no longer five years old in Lismore — but I am shocked by the power racism still has over me

image.altText: Man wearing glasses holding a laptop smiling to camera.

items.synopsis: "Live shopping" is on the rise in Indonesia, but the country's government plans to crack down on the trend.

title.children: Dr Lee made $800k in three hours selling products online. Some say that must stop

image.altText: Composite image of three farmers standing in front of transmission towers.

items.synopsis: Farmers are locking their gates to level the playing field with power giants, and it's creating a roadblock on Australia's clean energy super highway. So what happens now?

title.children: Katherine didn't think a $500 gift card was a fair trade for unrestricted access to her land, so she shut the gate

image.altText: AFL legend Ron Barassi looks over a chessboard with figures of AFL players as the pieces.

items.synopsis: Aside from his brilliant footballing ability as a player and coach, Ronald Dale Barassi played a role in several of the key changes in Australian football. The game owes him a debt of thanks, writes Andrew McGarry.

title.children: Australian football is a national game with an Irish flair. Ron Barassi is the man to thank

image.altText: A street sign says 'NW U ST' under a traffic light. There are high rise apartments with balconies behind it.

items.synopsis: A teenage girl stabbed to death at McDonalds, and three teens hit with a volley of bullets in a playground, are two of many recent crimes to shake Washington DC. It's among US cities facing a post-pandemic surge in violence.

title.children: Young people are killing each other so frequently in the US capital, it's put its kids under curfew

image.altText: A man stands next to the  base of a tall tree in a fores

items.synopsis: Environmentalists say Tasmania's tall trees could become a major tourism drawcard like California's redwoods, but pot-holed winding roads and rough tracks make them hard to access.

title.children: Conservationists call Gandalf's Staff one of Australia's natural marvels. But very few to get to see it

image.altText: Brunette Cara Williams dressed up in a floral dress with blonde daughter in a pink dress and partner in a suit, smiling

items.synopsis: "We saw the stress and fatigue of other parents that had had more than one child, and we just said, 'we don't want to do that, why put the pressure on ourselves?'"

title.children: ‘Why put the pressure on ourselves?’ Why these families decided not to have another baby

image.altText: Ross Garnaut leans on a dead tree.

items.synopsis: Ross Garnaut says we have an opportunity to pursue "transformational economic reform" by tackling the rising problem of economic rents, writes Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: Australia would be raising $70 billion a year from the carbon price if it wasn't dismantled, Ross Garnaut says

image.altText: A man with a beard stand next to a younger man in a suit

items.synopsis: Morocco's elusive king was abroad when a devastating quake struck last week. When he returned home, there was mounting anger over the official response to the tragedy.

title.children: Rarely seen since he formed a bond with three brothers, Morocco's king returns home for quake fallout

image.altText: Having a cup of coffee with their dog on the verandah.

items.synopsis: After swapping their demanding jobs and cosmopolitan life in inner Melbourne for a bush block in Queensland, Jennifer Nini and Ben McGuire haven't looked back.

title.children: Leaving city crowds behind, this couple has found contentment by flower farming in country Queensland

image.altText: Russell Brand gestures as he talks.

items.synopsis: Three British news organisations report that comedian and social influencer Russell Brand is accused of rape, sexual assault and abuse based on allegations from four women who knew him over a seven-year period at the height of his fame.

title.children: UK comedian Russell Brand accused of rape and sexual assault

image.altText: Two feet in black socks stand on a scale, showing 116 kilograms.

items.synopsis: Any weight loss associated with the so-called 'budget Ozempic' is likely to be temporary and long-term use may be dangerous, write Nial Wheate and Jessica Pace.

title.children: Beware 'budget Ozempic': It won't help you lose weight long term, but it will make you dehydrated

image.altText: Exterior of the Royal Darwin Hospital's emergency and trauma centre.

items.synopsis: Police set up a crime scene in the Darwin CBD in the early hours of Saturday morning.

title.children: Man dies in hospital after stabbing in Darwin City

image.altText: Mark McDonnell shows his teeth

items.synopsis: In pain, unable to eat properly or smile – many Australians are wondering if dental services will ever be included in Medicare.

title.children: Australians left with rotting teeth, unable to smile in 'completely unaffordable' dental system

image.altText: Frida Deguise smiling on stage holding microphone, wearing hijab, with bright purple light behind her.

items.synopsis: These comedians are using humour to consider the tenets of their faith and break down damaging stereotypes. But it's not always an easy gig.

title.children: These comedians have made careers based on joking about their religion. But they're not always having fun

image.altText: mother unpacking shopping in kitchen with toddler on bench

items.synopsis: Australia's plastic packaging system is being overhauled, which is good news for conscious consumers like Nadene, but some remain sceptical about how much recycling can realistically be achieved.

title.children: Nadene feels she's fighting a losing battle to reduce plastics — but change is afoot that may make it easier

image.altText: A man sits behind his long working table in his workshop filled with multiple tools.

items.synopsis: Queensland carpenter Jason Porter is giving precious pieces of farming history new life — and new jobs — as glass-topped dining tables.

title.children: From the shed to the dining room, long-retired wool-sorting tables given new life and purpose

image.altText: Toby Greene salutes the crowd as he leads the Giants down the race

items.synopsis: GWS have booked a preliminary final date with Collingwood after a commanding win over Port Adelaide, where a returning superstar stole the show as the Power's gun midfield was taken apart. Here are five quick hits.

title.children: Five quick hits — Coniglio leads a crushing Giants win as Power's midfield crumbles under pressure

image.altText: A close up of a dead snake with green eyes

items.synopsis: A 10-year-old boy became the first recipient of taipan antivenom in 1955 and survived. But there was no such luck for Kevin Budden, who captured the first snake of its kind for milking five years earlier, but died in the process.

title.children: When Bruce was bitten by a taipan as a child, his life was saved thanks to a reptile enthusiast who paid the ultimate price

image.altText: Shaun Johnson and the Warriors smile on the sidelines of their NRL semifinal against the Knights.

items.synopsis: Shaun Johnson returns to ignite his Warriors, aided by a shocking start that left the Knights unable to pull off a second straight miracle. Here are five things you may have missed from Saturday night's second semifinal.

title.children: Five quick hits — Newcastle falls apart on kick-off and Shaun Johnson twists the knife

image.altText: An Australian female 1,500m athlete competing at the national championships in 2023.

items.synopsis: Linden Hall smashes her Australian mark at the prestigious season-ending meet in the United States, while compatriot Mackenzie Little finishes third in the javelin.

title.children: Aussie Hall sets national record at Diamond League final to finish season on a high

image.altText: An echidna makes its way across a road in the sunshine.

items.synopsis: Echidna breeding season provides opportunities to learn more about the elusive creatures, but echidnas on the move means they're also more likely to run into trouble with humans. Here's how you can help on both fronts.

title.children: Echidnas are mating, and scientists want you to keep an eye out for the elusive animals and their glittery poo

image.altText: An Australian male tennis player pumps his fist during a Davis Cup tie.

items.synopsis: Lleyton Hewitt's Australian squad roars into the finals of the men's showpiece teams event, with a 3-0 drubbing of Switzerland in Manchester.

title.children: Aussies thrash Swiss to power into Davis Cup finals

image.altText: A girl kicking a football in a backyard, while an adult watches on from the verandah.

items.synopsis: Carers step up out of love to provide children with a brighter future. But they say the system makes it challenging and is held together by goodwill.

title.children: 'Good people' are keeping children with family, but carers say they need more support

image.altText: A woman looks at a photo of her late mother.

items.synopsis: When her mum died in 2012, Sarah Powell was left feeling isolated and alone — but a camp for kids going through that same sense of loss and grief helped her process her emotions, and left her wanting to help others.

title.children: Sarah was 14 when her mum died — now, she helps other kids going through grief

image.altText: Sonia Dadger

items.synopsis: In the cramped room of a building in a secret location in Afghanistan, about 40 teenage girls gather to take part in an English class. Their teacher, Sonia Dadger, conducts the classes remotely more than 11,000 kilometres away.

title.children: The Sydney teacher whose secret students are 11,000 km away in Afghanistan

image.altText: In this concept image, a stadium shines brightly in Hobart under an pink evening sky.

items.synopsis: Growing concerns about the suitability of the Macquarie Point site for a 23,000-seat AFL stadium has fuelled speculation the home of Tasmania's prospective AFL team cannot be built without a major cost blowout.

title.children: Rockliff lashes 'knockers and blockers' over AFL stadium amid engineering claims

image.altText: A Same sex family with a child walk at sunset in a silhouette image.

items.synopsis: Ammar knows firsthand how tough life can be for Iraq's LGBT community, but soon it could get a whole lot worse as the Iraqi parliament mulls a proposed law to punish same-sex relationships with death.

title.children: Ammar didn't dare dream about a relationship in Iraq. Now in Australia, he's about to start a family

image.altText: Oil painting showing a woman sitting at a table drinking coffee, with a dachshund beside her.

items.synopsis: The French painter was a ‘magician with colour’ whose paintings betray quietly radical sensibilities - and whose portraits of his pets and his wife reveal tenderness and humour. Here are six paintings that reveal his gentle genius.

title.children: Hidden cats, sausage dogs, classy nudes and colour: Understanding gentle genius Pierre Bonnard
